text.p: Following are some of the leading stories in the Swedish papers on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Swedish households have begun to live on borrowed money or savings, figures from Statistics Sweden show. The bureau says that in the fourth quarter of 1996 Swedes' savings totalled a negative five billion crowns.
- Data from government think-tank KI shows order intake for export companies is strong but the domestic market continues to be weak.
- Volvo Cars managing director Tuve Johannesson says in an interview with an internal magazine that a Volvo car assembly factory will be built in the United States.
- Ericsson will launch three new types of mobile telephones in the coming weeks.
- Few immigrants are active members in Sweden's unions, figures show. There have been no improvements to this in the past decade, umbrella union group LO says.

- The conflict between the United States and Sweden was short with tension dissipating already on Thursday afternoon. Yesterday Sweden's Prime Minister Goran Persson accused the U.S. ambassador to Sweden of interfering in Sweden's domestic affairs after the ambassador criticised a decision to begin phasing out nuclear power.

- The European cultural capital project for 1998 was supposed to mean money for cultural investments in various sites around the country. But project leader Gunnar Svensson says he is still unsure how much or when the expected money will actually materialise.
- Riksbank Governor Urban Backstrom says Sweden risks landing in a situation of growth without the number of jobs increasing unless wage increases do not become lower than those in Western Europe.
- Five companies -- SCA, Sydkraft, SKF, Astra and Scania -- have increased the proportion they spend on research and development, but it is still Saab which spends the most by percentage.
- Truck maker Scania is opening an import company in Moscow on June 1. Autoliv ALIV.ST will be the first international car safety equipment maker to make inroads in Russia.

- Swedish information technology firm IFS does not meet criteria for a listing on the Stockholm Stock Exchange so it will instead seek to raise capital through SBI, a stock exchange for smaller companies.
- Autoliv AB says it will start producing seat belts at a plant in Dubna, Russia.
- Shares in Trustor fell almost three percent on Thursday. Lord Moyne, Jonathan Guinness, recently bought 17 percent of capital and 52 percent of votes in the group.
